subject: Economics
title: Antitrust in Tech: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
description: A 60-second lesson on Antitrust in Tech: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do.

hook.text: The US broke up Standard Oil in 1911 and AT&T in 1984. Now Google, Apple, Amazon, and Meta face antitrust suits.

buildup.text: Traditional antitrust focused on consumer harm: monopolies raise prices. But Big Tech often offers free products.

discovery.text: The new antitrust thinking: harm isn't just higher prices.

twist.text: Breaking up tech companies might backfire.

climax.text: Tech antitrust requires new economic thinking.

punchline.text: Antitrust law was built for a world of prices.

quiz.question: Why is traditional antitrust law difficult to apply to tech companies?
options: Many tech products are free, making traditional price-based consumer harm analysis inadequate
Tech companies always follow the rules
